alternate_names: Moth balls; Moth flakes; Camphor tar
symptoms: Stomach problems may not occur until 2 days after coming in contact with the poison. They can include:
The person may also have a fever. Over time, the following symptoms also may occur:
Note: People with a condition called glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency are more vulnerable to the effects of naphthalene.
Pain when urinating (may be blood in the urine)

title: Nitric acid poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms from swallowing nitric acid may include:
Symptoms from breathing in (inhaling) nitric acid may include:
If the poison touches your skin or eyes, you may have:
Throat swelling, which leads to breathing difficulty

title: Oxalic acid poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms of oxalic acid poisoning include:
Symptoms from getting oxalic acid on the skin or in the eyes include:
Burns and blisters where the acid contacted the skin, lips, tongue, and gums
Throat pain and swelling, which leads to difficulty breathing

title: Acetone poisoning
alternate_names: Dimethyl formaldehyde poisoning; Dimethyl ketone poisoning; Nail polish remover poisoning
symptoms: Below are symptoms of acetone poisoning or exposure in different parts of the body.
Person may have a fruity odor

title: Potassium carbonate poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms of potassium carbonate poisoning include:
Symptoms from getting potassium carbonate on the skin or in the eyes include:
Burns and severe pain in the mouth and throat
Throat swelling, which leads to difficulty breathing

title: Potassium hydroxide poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms from swallowing potassium hydroxide include:
Symptoms from getting potassium hydroxide on the skin or in the eyes include:
Burns and severe pain in the mouth and throat
Throat swelling, which leads to difficulty breathing

title: Boric acid poisoning
alternate_names: Borax poisoning
symptoms: The main symptoms of boric acid poisoning are blue-green vomit, diarrhea, and a bright red rash on the skin. Other symptoms may include:
Lack of desire to do anything (lethargy)
Twitching of facial muscles, arms, hands, legs, and feet

title: Sodium carbonate poisoning
alternate_names: Sal soda poisoning; Soda ash poisoning; Disodium salt poisoning; Carbonic acid poisoning; Washing soda poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms from swallowing sodium carbonate may include:
Symptoms from skin or eye contact may include:
Breathing problems due to throat swelling
Severe pain in the mouth, throat, chest, or abdominal area

title: Sodium hydroxide poisoning
alternate_names: Lye poisoning; Caustic soda poisoning
symptoms: Below are symptoms of sodium hydroxide poisoning or exposure in different parts of the body.
Throat swelling (which may also cause breathing difficulty)
Burns of the esophagus (food pipe) and stomach
Severe pain or burning in the nose, eyes, ears, lips, or tongue
Severe change in blood pH (too much or too little acid in the blood)
Holes in the skin or tissue under the skin

title: Sodium hypochlorite poisoning
alternate_names: Bleach; Clorox; Carrel-Dakin solution
symptoms: Watered-down (diluted) sodium hypochlorite generally causes only mild stomach irritation. Swallowing larger amounts can cause more serious symptoms. Industrial-strength bleach contains much higher concentrations of sodium hypochlorite, which may cause severe injury.

NEVER mix ammonia with sodium hypochlorite (bleach or bleach-containing products). This common household error produces chlorine, which is a toxic gas that can cause choking and serious breathing problems.
Symptoms of sodium hypochlorite poisoning may include:
Pain in the mouth or throat
Skin irritation of the exposed area, burns, or blistering
Throat swelling, which leads to difficulty breathing

title: Trisodium phosphate poisoning
alternate_names: Sodium orthophosphate poisoning; Trisodium orthophosphate poisoning; TSP poisoning
symptoms: Below are symptoms of trisodium phosphate poisoning or exposure in different parts of the body.
Throat swelling (which may also cause breathing difficulty)
Burns of the esophagus (food pipe) and stomach
Severe pain or burning in the nose, eyes, ears, lips, or tongue
Severe change in blood acid level
Holes in the skin or tissue under the skin

title: Ammonium hydroxide poisoning
alternate_names: Aqueous - ammonia
symptoms: Below are symptoms of ammonia exposure or poisoning in different parts of the body.
Breathing difficulty (if the ammonia is inhaled)
Throat swelling (can also cause breathing difficulty)
Severe pain or burning in the nose, eyes, ears, lips, or tongue
Burns of the esophagus (food pipe) and stomach
Severe change in pH (too much or too little acid in the blood, which leads to damage in all of the body organs)

title: Sulfuric acid poisoning
alternate_names: Battery acid poisoning; Hydrogen sulfate poisoning; Oil of vitriol poisoning; Matting acid poisoning; Vitriol brown oil poisoning
symptoms: Initial symptoms include severe pain on contact.
Symptoms from swallowing may also include:
Symptoms from breathing in the poison may include:
Symptoms from skin or eye contact may include:
Breathing difficulty due to throat swelling
Burns in the mouth and throat
Rapid development of low blood pressure (shock)
Severe pain in the mouth and throat

title: Cobalt poisoning
alternate_names: Cobalt chloride; Cobalt oxide; Cobalt sulfate
symptoms: Usually you have to be exposed to high levels of cobalt for weeks to months to have symptoms. However, it is possible to have some symptoms if you swallow a large amount of cobalt at one time.

The most worrisome form of cobalt poisoning occurs when you breathe it into your lungs. This usually will only happen in industrial settings where large amounts of drilling, polishing, or other processes release fine particles containing cobalt into the air. Breathing in this cobalt dust can lead to chronic lung problems. If you breathe in this substance for long periods, you will likely develop breathing problems that are similar to asthma or pulmonary fibrosis, such as shortness of breath and decreased exercise tolerance.
Cobalt poisoning that occurs from prolonged constant with your skin will likely cause irritation and rashes that go away slowly.

Swallowing a large amount of absorbable cobalt at one time is very rare and is likely not very dangerous. It may cause nausea and vomiting. However, absorbing a large amount of cobalt over longer periods of time can lead to serious health problems, such as:
Cardiomyopathy (a problem where your heart becomes big and floppy and has problems pumping blood)

title: Copper poisoning
symptoms: Swallowing large amounts of copper may cause:
Touching large amounts of copper can cause the hair to turn a different color (green). Breathing in copper dust and fumes may cause an acute syndrome of metal fume fever (MFF). People with MFF have:
Long-term exposure may cause lung inflammation and permanent scarring. This can lead to decreased lung function.
Yellow skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice)
Diarrhea (often bloody and may be blue in color)

title: Hydrochloric acid poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms from swallowing hydrochloric acid may include:
Symptoms from breathing in hydrochloric acid:
If the poison touches your skin or eyes, you may have:
Mouth and throat burn, causing severe pain
Breathing difficulty due to swelling of throat
Bluish color to lips and fingernails

title: Hydrofluoric acid poisoning
alternate_names: Fluorhydric acid
symptoms: If the poison touched your skin or eyes, you may have:
Hydrofluoric acid poisoning can have direct effects on the heart. It can lead to irregular, and sometimes life-threatening, heartbeats.
People who come into contact with this poison are likely to have a combination of the listed symptoms.
Burns to the mouth and throat causing severe pain
Breathing difficulty from throat and mouth swelling and burning
Collapse (from low blood pressure or shock)

title: Morphine overdose
symptoms: When you take the correct or prescribed dose of these medicines, side effects may occur. In addition to relieving pain, you may be drowsy, confused and in a daze, constipated, and possibly nauseated.
When you take too much of this medicine, symptoms become much more serious. Symptoms may develop in many body systems:
Spasms (pain) of the stomach or intestinal tract
Slow breathing that requires more effort
Muscle damage from being immobile while unresponsive

title: Naproxen sodium overdose
symptoms: Symptoms of naproxen sodium overdose include:
Agitation, confusion, incoherence (the person is not understandable)
Heartburn, stomach pain (possible bleeding in the stomach and intestines)

title: Pentobarbital overdose
alternate_names: Nembutal overdose; Pentosol overdose; Sopental overdose; Repocal overdose; Barbiturate overdose - pentobarbital
symptoms: Symptoms of a pentobarbital overdose may include:
Blurred or double vision, rapid side-to-side movement of eyes (nystagmus)
Coma (decreased level of consciousness and lack of responsiveness)
Weakness, uncoordinated movement, staggering gait (ataxia, seen commonly in children)

title: Nicotine poisoning
symptoms: Breathing that may be difficult, rapid, or even stopped
Fainting or even coma (lack of responsiveness)
Palpitations (fast and pounding heartbeat often followed by slow heart rate)

title: Oxazepam overdose
alternate_names: Benzodiazepine overdose - oxazepam
symptoms: Blurred or double vision, rapid side-to-side movement of eyesÂ (nystagmus)
Coma (decreased level of consciousness and lack of responsiveness)
Weakness, uncoordinated movement, staggering gait (ataxia, seen commonly in children)

alternate_names: PABA; Vitamin Bx
symptoms: Symptoms of an allergic reaction to PABA or PABA overdose include:Â
Note: Most PABA reactions are due to allergic reactions, not overdoses.
Eye irritation if it touches the eyes
Stupor (altered thinking and decreased level of consciousness)

title: Pentazocine overdose
symptoms: Pentazocine is a weak opioid. It may cause opioid withdrawal symptoms in people who use it as a substitute for stronger formulations. Symptoms of withdrawal may include:
Muscle damage from being immobile while in a coma
Spasms of the stomach or intestines (abdominal cramps)

title: Antidiarrheal drug overdose
alternate_names: Diarrhea medicine poisoning; Diphenoxylate and atropine poisoning
symptoms: Someone who has overdosed on this medicine may have some of these symptoms:
Note: Symptoms may take up to 12 hours to appear.
Apathy (loss of desire to do anything)
Slowdown or stoppage of the bowels
Coma (decreased level of consciousness, lack of responsiveness)
Dry mucous membranes in the mouth
Eye changes in pupil size (may be small, normal-sized, or large)
Eyes move quickly from side to side
Hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that aren't there)

title: Petroleum jelly overdose
alternate_names: Vaseline overdose
symptoms: These symptoms may occur from swallowing a large amount of petroleum jelly:
A large amount of petroleum jelly which gets in the eyes or nose, or is used on the skin, the eyes, nose, or skin may cause irritation of these tissues.
If petroleum jelly is aspirated (enters the breathing tube and lungs), symptoms may be more serious and may include:

alternate_names: PCP overdose; Angel dust overdose; Sernyl overdose; Wet overdose
symptoms: People who have used PCP can be dangerous to themselves and others. DO NOT try to approach an agitated person who you think has used PCP.
Catatonic trance (person does not talk, move, or react)

symptoms: Symptoms of an overdose of calcium carbonate and magnesium include:

Weakness, uncoordinated movement, staggering gait (ataxia, seen commonly in children)

symptoms: Symptoms from swallowing more than a tablespoon (15 milliliters) of this acid may include:
If the chemical touches your skin, symptoms may include:
If it gets in your eyes, you may have:

symptoms: Symptoms of a sulindac overdose may include:

title: Thioridazine overdose

Ulcers in the mouth, on the tongue, or in the throat
High or very low blood pressure
Breathing may stop in severe cases
Hypothermia (body temperature is lower than normal)

title: Tolmetin overdose
alternate_names: Tolmetin sodium overdose
symptoms: Below are symptoms of an overdose of tolmetin in different parts of the body.
Bleeding in the stomach and intestines

title: Trazodone overdose

symptoms: Below are symptoms of an overdose of trazodone in different parts of the body.

title: Acetaminophen and codeine overdose
alternate_names: Tylenol #3 overdose; Phenaphen with codeine overdose; Tylenol with codeine overdose
symptoms: Below are symptoms of an overdose of acetaminophen combined with codeine in different parts of the body.
Spasms of the stomach and intestines

title: Bacitracin overdose
alternate_names: Polysporin ointment overdose
symptoms: Bacitracin is very safe. However, getting it in the eyes may cause redness and some pain and itching.
Eating bacitracin in large amounts may cause stomach pain and vomiting.
In rare cases, bacitracin can cause an allergic reaction, often redness and itching of the skin. If the reaction is severe, there may be difficulty swallowing or breathing.

Bacitracin is still used as a body-wide (systemic) antibiotic in parts of the world. If it is given by injection, it may cause pain in the area of the shot or a skin rash. It can also cause nausea, vomiting, and bone marrow and kidney failure.
People who are sensitive to neomycin, another antibiotic that is used on the skin, may also be sensitive to bacitracin.

title: Camphor overdose
alternate_names: Vicks VapoRub overdose
symptoms: Burning of the mouth or the throat

title: Bacitracin zinc overdose
alternate_names: Cortisporin ointment overdose
symptoms: Bacitracin zinc is very safe. However, getting bacitracin zinc ointment intended for skin use in the eyes may cause redness, pain, and itching.
Eating bacitracin in large amounts may cause pain in your stomach, and you might throw up.
In rare cases, bacitracin zinc causes an allergic reaction, usually redness and itching of the skin. If the reaction is severe, there may be difficulty swallowing or breathing.

title: Zinc oxide overdose
alternate_names: Desitin overdose; Calamine lotion overdose
symptoms: Zinc oxide poisoning can cause these symptoms:

Most of the harmful effects of zinc oxide come from breathing in the gas form of zinc oxide at industrial sites in the chemical or welding industry. This leads to a condition known as metal fume fever. Symptoms of metal fume fever include a metallic taste in the mouth, fever, headache, chest pain, and shortness of breath. Symptoms start about 4 to 12 hours after breathing in the fumes and may result in serious injury to the lungs.

title: Aminophylline overdose
alternate_names: Theophylline overdose; Xanthine overdose
symptoms: The most serious life-threatening symptoms of theophylline overdose are seizures and disturbances in heart rhythm.
Confused thinking, poor judgment and agitation (psychosis when extreme)

title: Thiazide overdose
alternate_names: Diuretic anti-hypertensives overdose
symptoms: Symptoms of a thiazide overdose include:
Skin sensitive to sunlight, yellow skin
Vision problems (things you see look yellow)

title: Beta-blockers overdose
symptoms: Below are symptoms of a beta-blocker overdose in different parts of the body.
Low blood sugar is common in children with this type of overdose, and it can lead to nervous system symptoms.
Heart failure (shortness of breath and swelling of the legs)
Coma (decreased level of consciousness or unresponsiveness)

title: Caffeine overdose
symptoms: Symptoms of caffeine overdose in adults may include:
The acute symptoms of caffeine intoxication (overdose, poisoning) and generalized anxiety disorder are almost identical.
Muscles that are very tense, then very relaxed

title: Calcium-channel blocker overdose
symptoms: Symptoms of a calcium-channel blocker overdose include:
Agitation (hyperactivity) and delirium (confused thinking and possible hallucinations)

title: Cardiac glycoside overdose
alternate_names: Digoxin overdose; Digitoxin overdose; Lanoxin overdose; Purgoxin overdose; Allocar overdose; Corramedan overdose; Crystodigin overdose
symptoms: Symptoms may be vague, especially in the older people.
They may occur in different parts of the body. The ones with an asterisk (*) next to them usually occur only in chronic overdoses.
Allergic reaction, including possible Stevens-Johnson syndrome (serious rash and difficulty swallowing and breathing)

title: Corticosteroids overdose
symptoms: Symptoms of corticosteroid overdose can include:
Some of the above symptoms may develop even when corticosteroids are used correctly, and some are more likely to develop after chronic use or overuse.
Heart rhythm disturbances (rapid pulse, irregular pulse)
Swelling in lower legs, ankles, or feet
Weak bones (osteoporosis) and bone fractures (seen with long-term use)
Worsening of health conditions such as stomach inflammation, acid reflux, ulcers, and diabetes

title: Sports cream overdose
alternate_names: Ben-Gay overdose; Menthol and methyl salicylate overdose; Methyl salicylate and menthol overdose
symptoms: Below are symptoms of sports cream overdose or allergic reaction in different parts of the body.
Buildup of fluid in the lungs
Mild burn (in extremely high concentrations or repeated doses)
Nausea and vomiting, possibly with blood

title: Estrogen overdose
symptoms: Symptoms of an estrogen overdose include:
Excessive vaginal bleeding (2 to 7 days after overdose)

title: H2 receptor antagonists overdose
alternate_names: H2-blocker overdose; Cimetidine overdose; Tagamet overdose; Zantac overdose; Famotidine overdose; Pepcid overdose; Nizatidine overdose; Axid overdose
symptoms: Symptoms of an H2 receptor antagonist overdose are:
Abnormal heartbeat, including rapid or slow heartbeat
Hallucinations (seeing or hearing something that isn't there)
Yellowing of your skin (jaundice) and eyes, and dark urine (if your liver has been affected)

title: Laxative overdose
alternate_names: Laxative abuse
symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramping, and diarrhea are the most common symptoms of a laxative overdose. Dehydration and electrolyte (body chemicals and minerals) imbalance are more common in children than adults. Below are symptoms specific to the actual product.
Castor oil can cause gastrointestinal irritation.
Mineral oil can cause aspiration pneumonia, a condition where vomited stomach contents are inhaled into the lungs.
Products containing methylcellulose, carboxymethylcellulose, polycarbophil, or psyllium may cause choking or intestinal blockage if they are not taken with plenty of fluids.

title: Nitroglycerin overdose
symptoms: Below are symptoms of a nitroglycerin overdose in different parts of the body.
Bluish color to lips and fingernails

title: Oral hypoglycemics overdose
alternate_names: Diabetes pill overdose; Sulfonylurea overdose
symptoms: Symptoms of an overdose of this medicine include:
People who have had a stroke in the past may appear to be having another stroke if their blood sugar drops too low.
Apathy (lack of desire to do anything)
Coma (decreased level of consciousness and lack of responsiveness)
Convulsions (seizures, especially in infants and children)
Stupor (decreased level of consciousness plus confusion)

title: Piperonyl butoxide with pyrethrins poisoning
alternate_names: Pyrethrins poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms of poisoning from these products include:
Difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, wheezing
Eye irritation if it touches the eyes

title: Tetrahydrozoline poisoning
alternate_names: Tetryzoline; Murine; Visine

title: Multiple vitamin overdose
symptoms: Iron overdose may include vomiting, diarrhea (which may be bloody or dark), or weakness. People with severe overdoses may develop coma, low blood pressure, liver failure, lung injury, and death.

Calcium overdose can impair the functioning of the kidneys, increase the pH of the blood, and can cause nausea and vomiting, confusion or changes in thinking or mentation, itching, and in extreme cases irregular heartbeat.
Vitamin D overdose can contribute to high levels of calcium in the blood.
Vitamin A overdose can cause nausea and vomiting, dizziness, blurry vision.
Additional symptoms of a multivitamin overdose in different parts of the body may include:
EYES, EARS, NOSE, MOUTH, AND THROAT
Increased sensitivity of the eyes to light
Sensitivity to sun (more likely to sunburn)

title: Phenothiazine overdose
symptoms: Below are symptoms of a phenothiazine overdose in different parts of the body.
EYES, EARS, NOSE, MOUTH, AND THROAT
Some of these symptoms may occur, even when the medicine is taken properly.
Inability to completely empty the bladder (urinary retention)
Sores in the mouth, on the tongue or in the throat
Rapid, involuntary movements of the face (chewing, blinking, grimaces, and tongue movements)
Restlessness linked with repeated foot shuffling, rocking, or pacing (akathisia)
Tremor, motor tics that the person cannot control (dystonia)
Uncoordinated movement, slow movement, or shuffling (with long-term use or overuse)

title: Acetaminophen overdose

symptoms: Note: Symptoms may not occur until 12 or more hours after the acetaminophen was swallowed.
JaundiceÂ (yellow skin and whites of the eyes)

Neurologic symptoms (develop after the intestinal symptoms)
Heart problems may occur in rare cases:
There will likely not be any stomach or intestinal symptoms. Symptoms that can occur include:
In severe cases of chronic toxicity, there may also be nervous system and kidney problems, such as:
There will often be a combination of the acute and chronic symptoms listed above, including both nervous system and intestinal symptoms.
Coma (decreased level of consciousness, lack of responsiveness)

title: Bug spray poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms of using bug spray vary, depending on what type of spray it is.
Symptoms of swallowing sprays that contain pyrethrins are:
Below are symptoms of using sprays that contain DEET in different parts of the body.
HEART AND BLOOD (IF A LARGE AMOUNT OF DEET IS SWALLOWED)

DEET is especially dangerous for small children. Seizures may occur in small children who regularly have DEET on their skin for long periods of time. Care should be taken to use only products that have smaller amounts of DEET. These products should be used only for short periods of time. Products containing DEET probably should not be used on infants.
STOMACH AND INTESTINES (If SOMEONE SWALLOWS A SMALL AMOUNT OF DEET)
By far, the most serious complication of DEET poisonings is damage to the nervous system. Death is possible for people who develop nervous system damage from DEET.
Loss of alertness (stupor), from the blood oxygen level being out of balance
Tremors (if a large amount is swallowed)
Seizures (if a large amount is swallowed)
Upset stomach, including cramps, stomach pain, and nausea
Temporary burning and redness, if DEET is sprayed into these parts of the body. Washing the area will usually make the symptoms go away. Burns to the eye may require medicine.
Breathing difficulty due to throat swelling
Insomnia and mood changes. These symptoms may occur with long-term use of large amounts of DEET (over 50% concentration).
Hives or mild skin redness and irritation. These symptoms are usually mild and will go away when the product is washed off the skin.

More severe skin reactions that include blistering, burning, and permanent scars of the skin. These symptoms may occur when someone uses products that contain a large amount of DEET over a long period of time. Military personnel or game wardens may use these types of products.

title: Carbon monoxide poisoning
symptoms: When you breathe in carbon monoxide, the poison replaces the oxygen in your bloodstream. Your heart, brain, and body then become starved of oxygen.

Symptoms vary from person to person. Those at high risk for more severe bodily damage include young children, older adults, people with lung or heart disease, people who are at high altitudes, and smokers. Carbon monoxide can harm a fetus (unborn baby still in the womb).
Symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning may include:

Animals can also be poisoned by carbon monoxide. People who have pets at home may notice that their animals become weak or unresponsive from carbon monoxide exposure. Often the pets will get sick before humans.
Since many of these symptoms can occur with viral illnesses, carbon monoxide poisoning is often confused with these conditions. This can lead to a delay in getting help.
Breathing problems, including no breathing, shortness of breath, or rapid breathing
Chest pain (may occur suddenly in people with angina)

title: Wax poisoning
alternate_names: Crayons poisoning
symptoms: In general, wax is not poisonous. If a child eats a small amount of crayon, the wax will pass through the child's system without causing a problem. However, eating large amounts of wax or crayons can lead to intestinal obstruction.

People attempting to smuggle illegal drugs across international borders sometimes swallow packets of illegal substances that are layered in wax. If the packaging ruptures the drug is released, usually causing severe poisoning. The wax can then cause intestinal obstruction as well.

title: Pencil eraser swallowing
symptoms: Swallowing a pencil eraser may lead to an intestinal blockage, which can cause abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. Infants may become irritable.

title: Pencil swallowing
alternate_names: Graphite poisoning; Swallowing pencils
symptoms: Graphite is relatively nonpoisonous. There may be no symptoms. If symptoms do occur, they may include stomachache and vomiting, which could be from a bowel obstruction (blockage).
The person may choke while swallowing the pencil. This can cause symptoms such as repeated coughing, chest pain, shortness of breath, or rapid breathing.
Sometimes, children will place a piece of a pencil in their nose. This can cause symptoms such as nose pain and drainage, and breathing problems. Infants may become irritable.

title: Poisoning - fish and shellfish
alternate_names: Fish poisoning; Dinoflagellate poisoning; Seafood contamination; Paralytic shellfish poisoning; Ciguatera poisoning
symptoms: The harmful substances that cause ciguatera, scombroid, and shellfish poisonings are heat stable, so no amount of cooking will prevent you from becoming poisoned if you eat contaminated fish. Symptoms depend on the specific type of poisoning.
Ciguatera poisoning symptoms can occur 2 to 12 hours after eating the fish. They include:
Shortly after these symptoms develop, you will start to have strange sensations, which may include:
These symptoms may get worse if you drink alcohol with your meal.
Scombroid poisoning symptoms most often occur immediately after eating the fish. They may include:
Below are other well-known types of seafood poisoning, and their symptoms.

Paralytic shellfish poisoning: About 30 minutes after eating contaminated seafood, you may have numbness or tingling in your mouth. This sensation may spread down to your arms and legs. You may become very dizzy, have a headache, and, in some cases, your arms and legs may become temporarily paralyzed. Some people may also have nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, although these symptoms are much less common.

Neurotoxic shellfish poisoning: The symptoms are very similar to those of ciguatera poisoning. After eating contaminated clams or mussels, you may experience nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. These symptoms will be followed soon after by strange sensations that may include numbness or tingling in your mouth, headache, dizziness, and hot and cold temperature reversal.

Amnesic shellfish poisoning: This is a strange and rare form of poisoning that begins with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. These symptoms are followed by short-term memory loss, and other less common nervous system symptoms.
A feeling that your teeth are loose and about to fall out
Confusing hot and cold temperatures (for instance, you will feel like an ice cube is burning you, while a match is freezing your skin)
Low heart rate and low blood pressure (in very severe cases)
Breathing problems, including wheezing and chest tightness (in severe cases)
Extremely red skin on the face and body

title: Stonefish sting
symptoms: A stonefish sting causes intense pain and swelling at the site of the sting. Swelling can spread to an entire arm or leg within minutes.

title: Tarantula spider bite
symptoms: If a tarantula bites you, you may have pain at the site of the bite similar to a bee sting. The area of the bite may become warm and red. When one of these spiders is threatened, it rubs its hind legs across its own body surface and flicks thousands of tiny hairs toward the threat. These hairs have barbs that can pierce human skin. This causes causing swollen, itchy bumps to form. Itching may last for weeks.
If you are allergic to tarantula venom, these symptoms may occur:
Loss of blood flow to major organs (an extreme reaction)
Swelling at the site of the bite
Swelling of the lips and throat

title: Tick bite
symptoms: Watch for symptoms of tick-borne diseases in the weeks after a tick bite. These include muscle or joint aches, stiff neck, headache, weakness, fever, swollen lymph nodes, and other flu-like symptoms. Watch for a red spot or rash starting at the site of the bite (called "erythema migrans").
The symptoms below are from the bite itself, not from the diseases a bite may cause. Some of the symptoms are caused by one variety of tick or another, but may not be common to all ticks.
Severe pain at site, lasting several weeks (from some kinds of ticks)
Swelling at site (from some kinds of ticks)

title: Wasp sting
symptoms: Below are symptoms of a wasp sting in different parts of the body.
Note: The symptoms marked with an asterisk (*) are from an allergic reaction to the venom, not from the venom itself.
Swelling of throat, lips, tongue, and mouth *
Swelling and pain at site of sting

title: Black widow spider
symptoms: The first symptom of a black widow bite is usually pain similar to a pinprick. This is felt when the bite is made. Some people may not feel it. Minor swelling, redness, and a target-shaped sore may appear.
After 15 minutes to 1 hour, a dull muscle pain spreads from the bite area to the whole body.
The following symptoms can also occur:
Pregnant women may have contractions and go into labor.
If the bite is on the upper body, you will usually feel most of the pain in your chest.
If the bite is on your lower body, you will usually feel most of the pain in your abdomen.
Numbness and tingling around the bite site, then sometimes spreading out from the bite
Seizures (usually seen just before death in children who are bitten)
Very painful muscle cramps or spasms
Facial swelling in the hours after the bite (This pattern of swelling is sometimes confused with an allergy to the drug used in treatment.)

title: Brown recluse spider
alternate_names: Loxosceles reclusa
symptoms: When the spider bites you, you may feel a sharp sting or nothing at all. Pain usually develops within the first several hours after being bitten, and may become severe. Children may have more serious reactions.

In serious cases, blood supply is cut off from the area of the bite. This results in black tissue scarring (eschar) at the site. The eschar sloughs off after about 2 to 5 weeks, leaving an ulcer through skin and fatty tissue. The ulcer may take many months to heal and leave a deep scar.
Reddish or purplish color in a circle around bite
Large sore (ulcer) in the area of the bite
Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice)

title: Caterpillars
symptoms: Below are symptoms of exposure to caterpillar hairs in different parts of the body.
Mouth and throat burning and swelling
Vomiting, if caterpillar or caterpillar hairs are eaten
Severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis). This is rare.
A combination of symptoms including itching, nausea, headache, fever, vomiting, muscle spasms, tingling in the skin, and swollen glands. This is also rare.

title: Heroin overdose
alternate_names: Acetomorphine overdose; Diacetylmorphine overdose; Opiate overdose; Opioid overdose
symptoms: People use heroin to get high because of its effects of short-lived euphoria and blissful apathy. But if they overdose on it, they get extremely sleepy and may become unconsciousness and stop breathing. Most deaths from heroin are due to not breathing.
Below are symptoms of a heroin overdose in different parts of the body.
Extremely small pupils, sometimes as small as the head of a pin (pinpoint pupils)
Spasms of the stomach and intestines

title: Caladium plant poisoning
alternate_names: Alocasia plant poisoning; Angel wings plant poisoning; Colocasia plant poisoning; Heart of Jesus plant poisoning; Texas Wonder plant poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms from eating parts of the plant or from the plant touching the eye include:
Blistering and swelling in the mouth may be severe enough to prevent normal speaking and swallowing.
Burning in the mouth or throat
Damage to the outer clear layer (cornea) of the eye
Swelling and blistering in the mouth or tongue

title: Calla lily poisoning
symptoms: Blistering and swelling in the mouth may be severe enough to prevent normal speaking and swallowing.
Redness, swelling, pain, and burning of the eyes, and possible corneal damage

title: Dieffenbachia poisoning
alternate_names: Dumbcane poisoning; Leopard lily poisoning; Tuft root poisoning
symptoms: Blistering and swelling in the mouth may be severe enough to prevent normal speaking and swallowing.
Redness, swelling, pain, and burning of the eyes, and possible corneal damage

title: Elephant ear poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms of elephant ear poisoning are:
Blistering and swelling in the mouth may be severe enough to prevent normal speaking and swallowing.
Redness, pain, and burning of the eyes
Swelling of the tongue, mouth, and eyes

title: Jack-in-the-pulpit poisoning
alternate_names: Arisaema triphyllum poisoning; Bog onion poisoning; Brown dragon poisoning; Indian turnip poisoning; Wake robin poisoning; Wild turnip poisoning
symptoms: Blistering and swelling in the mouth may be severe enough to prevent normal speaking and swallowing.
Redness, swelling, pain, and burning of the eyes, and possible corneal damage

title: Jerusalem cherry poisoning
alternate_names: Christmas cherry poisoning; Winter cherry poisoning; Ground cherry poisoning
symptoms: The effects of Jerusalem cherry poisoning mostly affect the primarily gastrointestinal (often delayed 8 to 10 hours), and central nervous system. This type of poisoning can be very dangerous. Other symptoms may include:

title: Philodendron poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms of this type of poisoning include:
Blistering and swelling in the mouth may be severe enough to prevent normal speaking and swallowing.
Redness, swelling, pain, and burning of the eyes, and possible corneal damage
Swelling of the mouth and tongue

title: Pokeweed poisoning
alternate_names: American nightshade poisoning; Inkberry poisoning; Pigeon Berry poisoning; Pokeberry poisoning; Scoke poisoning; Virginia poke poisoning; Poke salad poisoning

title: Potato plant poisoning - green tubers and sprouts
alternate_names: Solanum tuberosum poisoning
symptoms: Effects are mostly gastrointestinal. They are often delayed 8 to 10 hours. Central nervous system effects may occur in large ingestions. These poisonings can be very dangerous.

title: Rhubarb leaves poisoning
alternate_names: Rheum officinale poisoning
symptoms: Blistering and swelling in the mouth may be severe enough to prevent normal speaking and swallowing.

title: Yew poisoning
symptoms: Altered mental status (stupor, confusion, decreased awareness)
Tremor (shaking of the arms or legs)

title: Foxglove poisoning
alternate_names: Willow-leaved foxglove poisoning; Revebjelle poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms for the heart and blood include:
Hallucinations, loss of appetite, and halos are most often seen in people who have been poisoned over a long period of time.

title: Jimsonweed poisoning
alternate_names: Angel's trumpet; Devil's weed; Thorn apple; Tolguacha; Jamestown weed; Stinkweed; Datura; Moonflower
symptoms: Symptoms of jimsonweed poisonings can affect various body systems.
EYES, EARS, NOSE, THROAT, AND MOUTH
Little to no urine production (urinary retention)

title: Lily of the valley poisoning
alternate_names: Liljekonvall
symptoms: Poisoning symptoms can affect many parts of the body.
EYES, EARS, NOSE, MOUTH, AND THROAT
Note: Depression, loss of appetite, and visual halos are usually only seen in chronic overdose cases.

title: Mistletoe poisoning
symptoms: Symptoms of mistletoe poisoning can affect many parts of the body.
EYES, EARS, NOSE, MOUTH, AND THROAT

title: Oleander poisoning
alternate_names: Rosebay poisoning; Yellow oleander poisoning; Thevetia peruviana poisoning
symptoms: Oleander poisoning can affect many parts of the body.
EYES, EARS, NOSE, MOUTH, AND THROAT
Note: Depression, loss of appetite, and halos are most often seen in chronic overdose cases.
Vision disturbances, including halos around objects

title: Poinsettia plant exposure
alternate_names: Christmas flower poisoning; Lobster plant poisoning; Painted leaf poisoning
symptoms: Poinsettia plant exposure can affect many parts of the body.

title: Poison ivy - oak - sumac
alternate_names: Sumac - poisonous; Oak - poisonous; Ivy - poisonous
symptoms: In addition to the skin, symptoms can affect the eyes and mouth.
The rash may be spread by touching undried sap and moving it around the skin.
The oil can also stick to animal fur, which explains why people often contract the skin irritation (dermatitis) from their outdoor pets.

title: Black nightshade poisoning
alternate_names: Nightshade poisoning; Morelle noire poisoning; Wonderberry poisoning
symptoms: Black nightshade poisoning can affect many areas of the body.
EYES, EARS, NOSE, MOUTH, AND THROAT

title: Blue nightshade poisoning
alternate_names: Bittersweet poisoning; Bitter nightshade poisoning; Scarlet berry poisoning; Weedy nightshade poisoning
symptoms: Blue nightshade poisoning can affect many parts of the body:

title: Carbolic acid poisoning
alternate_names: Phenol poisoning; Phenylic acid poisoning; Hydroxybenzene poisoning; Phenic acid poisoning; Benzenol poisoning
symptoms: Below are symptoms of carbolic acid poisoning in different parts of the body.
EYES, EARS, NOSE, MOUTH, AND THROAT
Severe burns in the mouth and food pipe (esophagus)
Trouble breathing (may be life threatening if inhaled)
Coma (decreased level of consciousness and lack of responsiveness)

title: Chlorophyll poisoning
symptoms: Chlorophyll is considered nonpoisonous. Most people who swallow chlorophyll have no symptoms. In rare cases, the following symptoms may occur:
If someone does swallow chlorophyll, their tongue may appear yellow or black, and their urine or stool may appear green. If chlorophyll touches the skin, it may lead to mild burning or itching.

title: Cyanoacrylates poisoning
alternate_names: Glue; Super Glue; Crazy Glue
symptoms: The skin sticks together when these products get on the skin. They can cause hives and other types of skin irritation. Serious injury may occur if the product comes in contact with the eye.
Cyanoacrylates have medical value when used properly.

title: Fuel oil poisoning
symptoms: Below are symptoms of fuel oil poisoning in different parts of the body.
Pain or burning in the nose, eyes, ears, lips, or tongue
Low blood pressure that develops rapidly
Throat swelling (which may also cause breathing difficulty)

title: Merbromin poisoning
alternate_names: Cinfacrom poisoning; Mercurochrome poisoning; Stellachrome poisoning
symptoms: Below are symptoms of merbromin poisoning in different parts of the body.
EYES, EARS, NOSE, MOUTH, AND THROAT
Swelling in the throat (can be severe and completely close the throat)

title: Myristica oil poisoning
alternate_names: Nutmeg oil; Myristicin
symptoms: Below are symptoms of myristica oil poisoning in different parts of the body.
Tremors (shaking of the arms or legs)

title: Paradichlorobenzene poisoning
symptoms: Below are symptoms of paradichlorobenzene poisoning in different parts of the body.

title: Stoddard solvent poisoning
alternate_names: Texsolve S poisoning; Varsol 1 poisoning
symptoms: Below are symptoms of Stoddard solvent poisoning in different parts of the body.
EYES, EARS, NOSE, MOUTH, AND THROAT
Severe pain or burning in the eyes, ears, nose, and mouth area
Throat swelling (which may also cause breathing difficulty)
Holes in the skin or underlying tissues

title: Calcium hydroxide poisoning
alternate_names: Hydrate - calcium; Lime milk; Slaked lime; Hydrated lime
symptoms: Below are symptoms of calcium hydroxide poisoning in different parts of the body.
Severe pain or burning in the nose, eyes, ears, lips, or tongue
Low blood pressure that develops rapidly (shock)
Severe change in the acid level in the blood (pH balance), which leads to damage in all of the body organs
Throat swelling (which may also cause breathing difficulty)
Holes (necrosis) in the skin or tissues underneath

title: Binge eating disorder
alternate_names: Eating disorder - binge eating; Eating - binge; Overeating - compulsive; Compulsive overeating
symptoms: A person with binge eating disorder:

Binge eating may occur on its own or with another eating disorder, such as bulimia. People with bulimia may eat large amounts of high-calorie foods, often in secret. After this binge eating, they often force themselves to vomit or take laxatives, or exercise vigorously.
Eats large amounts of food in a short period, for example, within 2 hours
Is not able to control overeating, for example is unable to stop eating or control the amount of food
Eats food very fast each time
Keeps eating even when full (gorging) or until uncomfortably full
Feels guilty, disgusted, ashamed, or depressed after eating so much

title: Rheumatic fever
alternate_names: Streptococcus - rheumatic fever; Strep throat - rheumatic fever; Streptococcus pyogenes - rheumatic fever; Group A streptococcus - rheumatic fever
symptoms: Rheumatic fever mainly affects children ages 5 to 15 who have had strep throat or scarlet fever. If it occurs, it develops about 14 to 28 days after these illnesses.
Symptoms can affect many systems in the body. General symptoms may include:
Skin changes may also occur, such as:
A condition that affects the brain and nervous system, called Sydenham chorea, can also occur. Symptoms of this condition are:
Heart problems, which may have no symptoms, or may lead to shortness of breath and chest pain
Cause pain, swelling, redness, and warmth
Mainly occur in the knees, elbows, ankles, and wrists
Change or move from one joint to another
Ring-shaped or snake-like skin rash on the trunk and upper part of the arms or legs
Loss of control of emotions, with bouts of unusual crying or laughing
Quick, jerky movements that mainly affect the face, feet, and hands

Older children and adults often complain of muffled hearing or a sense of fullness in the ear. Younger children may turn up the television volume because of hearing loss.

The pain may develop slowly over time, or come on suddenly after intense activity.
In the morning when you take your first steps
After standing or sitting for awhile
During walking, running, and jumping sports

title: Coronary heart disease
alternate_names: Heart disease, Coronary heart disease, Coronary artery disease; Arteriosclerotic heart disease; CHD; CAD
symptoms: In some cases, symptoms may be very noticeable. But, you can have the disease and not have any symptoms. This is more often true in the early stages of CHD.
Chest pain or discomfort (angina) is the most common symptom. You feel this pain when the heart is not getting enough blood or oxygen. The pain may feel different from person to person.
Some people have symptoms other than chest pain, such as:
It may feel heavy or like someone is squeezing your heart. You may feel it under your breast bone (sternum). You may also feel it in your neck, arms, stomach, or upper back.
The pain most often occurs with activity or emotion. It goes away with rest or a medicine called nitroglycerin.
Other symptoms can include shortness of breath and fatigue with activity (exertion), or even feeling lightheaded or passing out with exertion.

title: Anemia caused by low iron - children

symptoms: Mild anemia may have no symptoms. As the iron level and blood counts become lower, your child may:
With more severe anemia, your child may have:
Feel tired or weak all the time
Blue-tinged or very pale whites of eyes

title: Complex regional pain syndrome
alternate_names: CRPS; RSDS; Causalgia - RSD; Shoulder-hand syndrome; Reflex sympathetic dystrophy syndrome; Sudeck atrophy; Pain - CRPS
symptoms: The key symptom is pain that:
In most cases, CRPS has three stages. But, CRPS does not always follow this pattern. Some people develop severe symptoms right away. Others stay in the first stage.
If pain and other symptoms are severe or long-lasting, many people may experience depression or anxiety.
Is intense and often burning and is much stronger than would be expected for the type of injury that occurred.
Gets worse, rather than better over time.
Begins at the point of injury, but may spread to the whole limb, or to the arm or leg on the opposite side of the body.
Changes in skin temperature, switching between warm or cold
Faster growth of nails and hair
Severe burning, aching pain that worsens with the slightest touch or breeze
Skin that slowly becomes blotchy, purple, pale, or red; thin and shiny; swollen; more sweaty
Nails that are cracked and break more easily
Limited movement in limb because of tightened muscles and tendons (contracture)

title: West Nile virus infection
alternate_names: Encephalitis - West Nile; Meningitis - West Nile
symptoms: Symptoms may occur 1 to 14 days after becoming infected. Mild disease, generally called West Nile fever, may cause some or all of the following symptoms:
These symptoms usually last for 3 to 6 days, but may last a month.
More severe forms of disease are called West Nile encephalitis or West Nile meningitis, depending on what part of the body is affected. The following symptoms can occur, and need prompt attention:
Confusion or change in ability to think clearly
Weakness of one arm or leg

title: Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)
alternate_names: SARS; Respiratory failure - SARS; SARS coronavirus; SARS-CoV
symptoms: Most people who get SARS will have symptoms.
In some people, the lung symptoms get worse during the second week of illness, even after the fever has stopped.
Cough, usually starts 2 to 7 days after other symptoms

title: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder
alternate_names: PMDD; Severe PMS; Menstrual disorder - dysphoric
symptoms: The symptoms of PMDD are similar to those of PMS. However, they are very often more severe and debilitating. They also include at least one mood-related symptom. Symptoms occur during the week just before menstrual bleeding. They most often get better within a few days after the period starts.
Here is a list of common PMDD symptoms:
Lack ofÂ interest in daily activities and relationships
Sadness or hopelessness, possibly thoughts of suicide
Mood swings sometimes with bouts of crying
Irritability or anger that affects other people
Bloating, breast tenderness, headaches, and joint or muscle pain

symptoms: Early lung cancer may not cause any symptoms.
Other symptoms that may be due to NSCLC, often in the late stages:
These symptoms can be due to other, less serious conditions. It is important to talk to your health care provider if you have symptoms.
Cough that does not go away

title: Bruise
alternate_names: Contusion; Hematoma
symptoms: Main symptoms are pain, swelling, and skin discoloration. The bruise begins as a pinkish red color that can be very tender to touch. It is often difficult to use the muscle that has been bruised. For example, a deep thigh bruise is painful when you walk or run.
Eventually, the bruise changes to a bluish color, then greenish-yellow, and finally returns to the normal skin color as it heals.

title: Postpartum depression
alternate_names: Depression - postpartum; Postnatal depression; Postpartum psychological reactions
symptoms: Feelings of anxiety, irritation, tearfulness, and restlessness are common in the week or two after you have your baby. These postpartum feelings are often called the "baby blues." They almost always go away soon, without the need for treatment.
Postpartum depression may occur when the baby blues do not fade away or when signs of depression start 1 or more months after childbirth.
The symptoms of postpartum depression are the same as the symptoms of depression that occurs at other times in life. Along with a sad or depressed mood, you may have some of the following symptoms:
A mother with postpartum depression may also:
Feeling like you are withdrawn or unconnected
Lack of pleasure or interest in most or all activities
Problems doing tasks at home or work
Be unable to care for herself or her baby.
Be afraid to be alone with her baby.

Have negative feelings toward the baby or even think about harming the baby. (Although these feelings are scary, they are almost never acted on. Still, you should tell your health care provider about them right away.)
Worry intensely about the baby or have little interest in the baby.

title: Fibroadenoma of the breast
alternate_names: Breast lump - fibroadenoma; Breast lump - noncancerous; Breast lump - benign
symptoms: Fibroadenomas are usually single lumps. Some women have several lumps that may affect both breasts.
The lumps may be any of the following:
The lumps have smooth, well-defined borders. They may grow in size, especially during pregnancy. Fibroadenomas often get smaller after menopause (if a woman is not taking hormone therapy).

title: Gangrene
symptoms: The symptoms depend on the location and cause of the gangrene. If the skin is involved, or the gangrene is close to the skin, the symptoms may include:

Discoloration (blue or black if skin is affected; red or bronze if the affected area is beneath the skin)
Loss of feeling in the area (which may happen after severe pain in the area)
Gas in tissues beneath the skin

Symptoms depend on the tumor's size, location, how far it has spread, and whether there is brain swelling. The most common symptoms are:
Headaches caused by brain tumors may:
Other symptoms that may occur with a pituitary tumor:
Changes in the person's mental function
Weakness in one part of the body
Be worse when the person wakes up in the morning, and clear up in a few hours
Occur with vomiting, confusion, double vision, weakness, or numbness
Get worse with coughing or exercise, or with a change in body position
Change in alertness (including sleepiness, unconsciousness, and coma)
Changes in hearing, taste, or smell
Changes that affect touch and the ability to feel pain, pressure, different temperatures, or other stimuli
Dizziness or abnormal sensation of movement (vertigo)
Eye problems such as eyelid drooping, pupils of different sizes, uncontrollable eye movement, vision difficulties (including decreased vision, double vision, or total loss of vision)
Lack of control over the bladder or bowels
Loss of balance or coordination, clumsiness, trouble walking
Muscle weakness in the face, arm, or leg (usually on just one side)
Numbness or tingling on one side of the body
Personality, mood, behavior, or emotional changes

symptoms: These are examples of emotional abuse:
These are signs that a child may be emotionally abused. They may have any of the following:

These are signs that a child may be neglected. The child may:
Not providing the child with a safe environment. The child witnesses violence or severe abuse between parents or adults.
Threatening the child with violence or abandonment.
Constantly criticizing or blaming the child for problems.
The child's parent or caregiver does not show concern for the child, and refuses help from others for the child.

Leaving a child alone for a long time. This is called abandonment.

title: Apnea of prematurity
alternate_names: Apnea - newborns; AOP; As and Bs; A/B/D; Blue spell - newborns; Dusky spell - newborns; Spell - newborns; Apnea - neonatal
symptoms: The breathing pattern of newborns is not always regular and may be called "periodic breathing." This pattern is even more likely in newborns born early. It consists of episodes of either shallow breathing or short pauses in breathing lasting just a few seconds. These episodes are then followed by periods of regular breathing. This is generally considered a normal pattern and can be expected in less mature and even some full-term babies. However, the pattern of breathing, length of breathing pauses, and the age of the baby are both important when deciding if it needs to be further evaluated.
Apnea episodes or "events" that last longer than 20 seconds are considered serious. The baby may also have a:
Drop in heart rate. This heart rate drop is called bradycardia (also called a "brady").
Drop in oxygen level (oxygen saturation). This is called desaturation (also called a "desat").

title: Hyperglycemia - infants
alternate_names: High blood sugar - infants; High blood glucose level - infants
symptoms: Babies with hyperglycemia often have no symptoms.

Sometimes, babies with high blood sugar will produce large amounts of urine and become dehydrated. High blood sugar may be a sign that the baby has added stress on the body due to problems such as an infection or heart failure.

title: Low calcium level  - infants
alternate_names: Hypocalcemia - infants
symptoms: Babies with hypocalcemia often have no symptoms. Sometimes, babies with low blood calcium levels are jittery or have tremors or twitching. Rarely, they have seizures.
These babies may also have a slow heart rate and low blood pressure.

title: Osteopenia - premature infants
alternate_names: Neonatal rickets; Brittle bones - premature infants; Weak bones - premature infants; Osteopenia of prematurity
symptoms: Most premature infants born before 30 weeks have some degree of osteopenia, but will not have any physical symptoms.
Infants with severe osteopenia may have decreased movement or swelling of an arm or leg due to an unknown fracture.

title: Periventricular leukomalacia
alternate_names: PVL; Brain injury - infants; Encephalopathy of prematurity

title: Transient tachypnea - newborn
alternate_names: TTN; Wet lungs - newborns; Retained fetal lung fluid; Transient RDS; Prolonged transition; Neonatal - transient tachypnea
symptoms: Newborns with TTN have breathing problems soon after birth, usually starting within 1 to 2 hours.
Rapid breathing, which may occur with noises such as grunting
Flaring nostrils or movements between the ribs or breastbone known as retractions

title: Osteonecrosis
alternate_names: Avascular necrosis; Bone infarction; Ischemic bone necrosis; AVN; Aseptic necrosis
symptoms: There are no symptoms in the early stages. As bone damage worsens, you may have the following symptoms:
Pain in the joint that may increase over time and becomes severe if the bone collapses
Pain that occurs even at rest
Groin pain, if the hip joint is affected
Limping, if the condition occurs in the leg
Difficulty with overhead movement, if the shoulder joint is affected
Worsening arthritic symptoms in the joint when the condition deteriorates

title: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)
alternate_names: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus; Hospital-acquired MRSA (HA-MRSA); Staph - MRSA; Staphylococcal - MRSA
symptoms: It is normal for healthy people to have staph on their skin. Many of us do. Most of the time, it does not cause an infection or any symptoms. This is called "colonization" or "being colonized." Someone who is colonized with MRSA can spread it to other people.

A sign of a staph skin infection is a red, swollen, and painful area on the skin. Pus or other fluids may drain from this area. It may look like a boil. These symptoms are more likely to occur if the skin has been cut or rubbed, because this gives the MRSA germ a way to enter your body. Symptoms are also more likely in areas where there is more body hair, because the germ can get into hair follicles.

MRSA infection in people who are in health care facilities tends to be severe. These infections may be in the bloodstream, heart, lungs or other organs, urine, or in the area of a recent surgery. Some symptoms of these severe infections may include:

The avian influenza virus in humans causes typical flu-like symptoms, such as:

title: Parathyroid cancer
alternate_names: Parathyroid carcinoma
symptoms: Symptoms of parathyroid cancer are mainly caused by a high level of calcium in the blood (hypercalcemia), and may affect different parts of the body.

title: Thyroid nodule
alternate_names: Thyroid adenoma - nodule; Thyroid carcinoma - nodule; Thyroid cancer - nodule; Thyroid incidentaloma; Hot nodule; Cold nodule; Thyrotoxicosis - nodule; Hyperthyroidism - nodule
symptoms: Most thyroid nodules do not cause symptoms.
Large nodules can press against other structures in the neck. This can cause symptoms such as:
Nodules that produce thyroid hormones will likely cause symptoms of an overactive thyroid gland, including:
Older people with a nodule that produces too much thyroid hormone may have only vague symptoms, including:
Thyroid nodules are sometimes found in people who have Hashimoto disease. Hashimoto disease may cause symptoms of an underactive thyroid gland, such as:

Very often, thyroid nodules produce no symptoms. Health care providers often find thyroid nodules during a routine physical exam or imaging tests that are done for another reason. A few people have thyroid nodules that are big enough that they notice the nodule on their own and ask their provider to examine their neck.
Problems breathing, especially when lying down flat
Feeling cold when other people do not

title: Gonorrhea
alternate_names: Clap; The drip
symptoms: Symptoms of gonorrhea most often appear 2 to 5 days after infection. However, it may take up to a month for symptoms to appear in men.

Some people do not have symptoms. They may not know that they have caught the infection, so do not seek treatment. This increases the risk of complications and the chances of passing the infection on to another person.
Symptoms in women can be very mild. They can be mistaken for another type of infection. They include:
If the infection spreads to the bloodstream, symptoms include:
Need to urinate urgently or more often
Discharge from the penis (white, yellow, or green in color)
Red or swollen opening of penis (urethra)
Severe pain in the lower abdomen (if the infection spreads to the fallopian tubes and uterus area)
Fever (if the infection spreads to the fallopian tubes and uterus area)
Abnormal vaginal discharge with greenish, yellow or foul smelling discharge

title: Atrial myxoma
alternate_names: Cardiac tumor - myxoma; Heart tumor - myxoma
symptoms: Many myxomas will not cause symptoms. These are often discovered when an imaging study (echocardiogram, MRI, CT) is done for another reason.
Symptoms may occur at any time, but often they go along with a change in body position.
Symptoms of a myxoma may include:

The symptoms and signs of left atrial myxomas often mimic mitral stenosis (narrowing of the valve between the left atrium and the left ventricle). Right atrial myxomas rarely produce symptoms until they have grown to be quite large (5 inches wide, or 13 cm).
Breathing difficulty when lying flat or on one side or the other
Sensation of feeling your heart beat (palpitations)
Symptoms due to embolism of tumor material
Bluish skin, especially on the fingers (Raynaud phenomenon)
Curvature of nails accompanied by soft tissue swelling (clubbing) of the fingers
Fingers that change color upon pressure or with cold or stress
Swelling in any part of the body

title: Hydrocodone/oxycodone overdose
alternate_names: Overdose - hydrocodone; Overdose - oxycodone; Vicodin overdose; Percocet overdose; Percodan overdose; MS Contin overdose; OxyContin overdose
symptoms: When you take the correct or prescribed dose of these medicines, side effects may occur. In addition to relieving pain, you may be drowsy, confused and in a daze, constipated, and possibly nauseated.
When you take too much of these medicines, symptoms become much more serious. Symptoms may develop in many body systems:
Spasms (pain) of the stomach or intestinal tract
Slow breathing that requires more effort
Muscle damage from being immobile while unresponsive

title: Morton neuroma

symptoms: In rare cases, nerve pain occurs in the space between the 2nd and 3rd toes. This is not a common form of Morton neuroma, but symptoms and treatment are similar.
Numbness and tingling in the space between the 3rd and 4th toes
Sharp, shooting, or burning pain in the ball of the foot and sometimes toes
Pain that increases when wearing tight shoes, high heels, or pressing on the area
Pain that gets worse over time

title: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome
alternate_names: OHSS
symptoms: The symptoms of OHSS can range from mild to severe. Most women with the condition have mild symptoms such as:
In rare cases, women can have more serious symptoms, including:
Rapid weight gain (more than 10 pounds or 4.5 kilograms in 3 to 5 days)
Severe pain or swelling in the belly area

title: Fuchs dystrophy
alternate_names: Fuchs' dystrophy; Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy; Fuchs' corneal dystrophy
symptoms: Eye sensitivity to light and glare
Foggy or blurred vision, at first only in the mornings

title: Lymphangitis
alternate_names: Inflamed lymph vessels; Inflammation - lymph vessels; Infected lymph vessels; Infection - lymph vessels
symptoms: Enlarged and tender lymph nodes (glands) -- usually in the elbow, armpit, or groin
Red streaks from the infected area to the armpit or groin (may be faint or obvious)
Throbbing pain along the affected area

title: Obesity

title: Intraventricular hemorrhage of the newborn
alternate_names: IVH - newborn; GMH-IVH
symptoms: There may be no symptoms. The most common symptoms seen in premature infants include:
Changes in blood pressure and heart rate

title: Neonatal weight gain and nutrition
alternate_names: Newborn nutrition; Nutritional needs - premature infants

title: Neonatal sepsis
alternate_names: Sepsis neonatorum; Neonatal septicemia; Sepsis - infant
symptoms: Infants with neonatal sepsis may have the following symptoms:
Yellow skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice)

title: Glomerular filtration rate
alternate_names: GFR; Estimated GFR; eGFR

title: Low blood sugar - newborns
alternate_names: Neonatal hypoglycemia
symptoms: Infants with low blood sugar may not have symptoms. If your baby has one of the risk factors for low blood sugar, nurses in the hospital will check your baby's blood sugar level, even if there are no symptoms.
Also, the blood sugar level is usually checked for babies with these symptoms:
Breathing problems, such as pauses in breathing (apnea), rapid breathing, or a grunting sound

title: Myocarditis - pediatric
symptoms: Symptoms may be mild at first and hard to detect. Sometimes in newborns and infants, symptoms may appear suddenly.
Symptoms in children over age 2 may also include:
Failure to thrive or poor weight gain
Fever and other symptoms of infection
Low urine output (a sign of decreasing kidney function)
Pale, cool hands and feet (a sign of poor circulation)
Swelling (edema) in the legs, feet, and face

title: Hydrops fetalis
symptoms: Symptoms depend on the severity of the condition. Mild forms may cause:
Bruising or purplish bruise-like spots on the skin

title: Bilirubin encephalopathy
alternate_names: Bilirubin-induced neurologic dysfunction (BIND); Kernicterus
symptoms: The symptoms depend on the stage of BE. Not all babies with kernicterus on autopsy have had definite symptoms.
Extreme sleepiness (lethargy) and low muscle tone (hypotonia)
May have arched back with neck hyperextended backwards, high muscle tone (hypertonia)
Muscle rigidity, markedly arched back with neck hyperextended backwards

title: Tracheomalacia - acquired
alternate_names: Secondary tracheomalacia
symptoms: Breathing problems that get worse with coughing, crying, or upper respiratory infections, such as a cold
Breathing noises that may change when body position changes, and improve during sleep

title: Quadruple screen test
alternate_names: Quad screen; Multiple marker screening; AFP plus; Triple screen test; AFP maternal; MSAFP; 4-marker screen; Down syndrome - quadruple; Trisomy 21 - quadruple; Turner syndrome - quadruple; Spina bifida - quadruple; Tetralogy - quadruple; Duodenal atresia - quadruple; Genetic counseling - quadruple; Alpha-fetoprotein quadruple; Human chorionic gonadotropin - quadruple; hCG - quadruple; Unconjugated estriol - quadruple; uE3 - quadruple; Pregnancy - quadruple; Birth defect - quadruple; Quadruple marker test; Quad test; Quadruple marker screen

title: Pneumothorax - infants
alternate_names: Pulmonary air leak; Pneumothorax - neonatal
symptoms: Many infants with pneumothorax do not have symptoms. When symptoms do occur, they can include:
Use of additional chest and abdominal muscles to aid breathing (retractions)

title: Neonatal abstinence syndrome
alternate_names: NAS; Neonatal abstinence symptoms; NOWS; Neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome
symptoms: The symptoms of NAS depend on:

Symptoms often begin within 1 to 3 days after birth, but may take up to a week to appear. Because of this, the baby will most often need to stay in the hospital for observation and monitoring for up to a week.
The type of drug the mother used
How the body breaks down and clears the drug (influenced by genetic factors)
How much of the drug she was taking
How long she used the drug
Whether the baby was born full-term or early (premature)

title: Absent pulmonary valve
alternate_names: Absent pulmonary valve syndrome; Congenital absence of the pulmonary valve; Pulmonary valve agenesis; Cyanotic heart disease - pulmonary valve; Congenital heart disease - pulmonary valve; Birth defect heart - pulmonary valve
symptoms: Symptoms can vary depending on which other defects the infant has, but may include:

title: Coronary artery fistula
alternate_names: Congenital heart defect - coronary artery fistula; Birth defect heart - coronary artery fistula
symptoms: Infants with this condition often do not have any symptoms.
If symptoms do occur, they can include:

title: Double aortic arch
alternate_names: Aortic arch anomaly; Double arch; Congenital heart defect - double aortic arch; Birth defect heart - double aortic arch
symptoms: Because symptoms of double aortic arch are often mild, the problem may not be discovered until the child is a few years old.

The double aortic arch may press on the trachea and esophagus, leading to trouble breathing and swallowing. The severity of the symptoms depends on how much the aortic arch is pressing on these structures.

title: Eisenmenger syndrome
alternate_names: Eisenmenger complex; Eisenmenger disease; Eisenmenger reaction; Eisenmenger physiology; Congenital heart defect - Eisenmenger; Cyanotic heart disease - Eisenmenger; Birth defect heart - Eisenmenger; Eisenmenger's syndrome
symptoms: Bluish lips, fingers, toes, and skin (cyanosis)
Numbness and tingling of fingers and toes
Swelling in the joints caused by too much uric acid (gout)

title: Vascular ring
alternate_names: Right aortic arch with aberrant subclavian and left ligamentum arteriosus; Congenital heart defect - vascular ring; Birth defect heart - vascular ring
symptoms: Some children with a vascular ring never develop symptoms. However, in most cases, symptoms are seen during infancy. Pressure on the windpipe (trachea) and esophagus can lead to breathing and digestive problems. The more the ring presses down, the more severe the symptoms will be.
Eating may make breathing symptoms worse.
Digestive symptoms are rare, but may include:

title: Aortopulmonary window
alternate_names: Aortopulmonary septal defect; Aortopulmonary fenestration; Congenital heart defect - aortopulmonary window; Birth defect heart - aortopulmonary window
symptoms: If the defect is small, it may not cause any symptoms. However, most defects are large.
Poor eating and lack of weight gain

title: Vitamin K deficiency bleeding of the newborn
alternate_names: Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn (HDN)
symptoms: Vitamin K deficiency causes bleeding. The most common areas of bleeding include:
Gastrointestinal tract (resulting in blood in the baby's bowel movements)
Mucous membranes (such as the lining of the nose and mouth)
Places where there has been a needle stick
Seizures (convulsions) or abnormal behavior due to bleeding inside the skull

title: Ebstein anomaly
alternate_names: Ebstein's anomaly; Ebstein's malformation; Congenital heart defect - Ebstein; Birth defect heart - Ebstein; Cyanotic heart disease - Ebstein
symptoms: The abnormality can be slight or very severe. Therefore, the symptoms can also range from mild to very severe. Symptoms can develop soon after birth, and can include bluish-colored lips and nails due to low blood oxygen levels. In severe cases, the baby appears very sick and has trouble breathing. In mild cases, the affected person may be asymptomatic for many years, sometimes even permanently.
Symptoms in older children may include:

title: Hearing loss - infants
alternate_names: Deafness - infants; Hearing impairment - infants; Conductive hearing loss - infants; Sensorineural hearing loss - infants; Central hearing loss - infants
symptoms: Signs of hearing loss in infants vary by age. For example:

Some children may not be diagnosed with hearing loss until they are in school. This is true even if they were born with hearing loss. Inattention and falling behind in class work may be signs of undiagnosed hearing loss.
A newborn baby with hearing loss may not startle when there is a loud noise nearby.
Older infants, who should respond to familiar voices, may show no reaction when spoken to.
Children should be using single words by 15 months, and simple 2-word sentences by age 2. If they do not reach these milestones, the cause may be hearing loss.

title: Anomalous left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
alternate_names: Anomalous origin of the left coronary artery arising from the pulmonary artery; ALCAPA; ALCAPA syndrome; Bland-White-Garland syndrome; Congenital heart defect - ALCAPA; Birth defect - ALCAPA
symptoms: Symptoms of ALCAPA in an infant include:
Symptoms can appear within the first 2 months of the baby's life.
Symptoms of pain or distress in the baby (often mistaken for colic)

title: Endocardial cushion defect
alternate_names: Atrioventricular (AV) canal defect; Atrioventricular septal defect; AVSD; Common AV orifice; Ostium primum atrial septal defects; Congenital heart defect - ECD; Birth defect - ECD; Cyanotic disease - ECD
symptoms: Bluish skin color, also known as cyanosis (the lips may also be blue)
Failure to gain weight and grow
Swollen legs or abdomen (rare in children)

title: Bicuspid aortic valve
alternate_names: Bicommissural aortic valve; Valvular disease - bicuspid aortic valve; BAV
symptoms: Most of the time, BAV is not diagnosed in infants or children because it causes no symptoms. However, the abnormal valve can leak or become narrow over time.
Symptoms of such complications may include:
If a baby has other congenital heart problems, they may cause symptoms that will lead to the discovery of a BAV.

title: Dextrocardia
alternate_names: Cyanotic heart defect - dextrocardia; Congenital heart defect - dextrocardia; Birth defect - dextrocardia
symptoms: There are no symptoms of dextrocardia if the heart is normal.
Conditions that may include dextrocardia may cause the following symptoms:
Failure to grow and gain weight

title: Double inlet left ventricle
alternate_names: DILV; Single ventricle; Common ventricle; Univentricular heart; Univentricular heart of the left ventricular type; Congenital heart defect - DILV; Cyanotic heart defect - DILV; Birth defect - DILV
symptoms: Bluish color to the skin and lips (cyanosis) due to low oxygen in the blood
Failure to gain weight and grow
Poor feeding from becoming tired easily

title: Double outlet right ventricle
alternate_names: DORV; Taussig-Bing anomaly; DORV with doubly-committed VSD; DORV with noncommitted VSD; DORV with subaortic VSD; Congenital heart defect - DORV; Cyanotic heart defect - DORV; Birth defect - DORV
symptoms: Poor feeding from becoming tired easily
Bluish color of the skin and lips (cyanosis)
Clubbing (thickening of the nail beds) of toes and fingers (late sign)
Failure to gain weight and grow

title: High blood pressure in infants
alternate_names: Hypertension - infants
symptoms: Most babies with high blood pressure will not have symptoms. Instead, symptoms may be related to the condition causing the high blood pressure. These symptoms may include:
Symptoms that may appear if the baby has very high blood pressure include:
Failure to grow and gain weight

symptoms: Symptoms include sudden blurring or vision loss in all or part of one eye.

title: Low back pain - chronic
alternate_names: Nonspecific back pain; Backache - chronic; Lumbar pain - chronic; Pain - back - chronic; Chronic back pain - low
symptoms: Symptoms may include any of the following:
Low back pain can differ from person to person. The pain may be mild, or it can be so severe that you cannot move.
Depending on the cause of your back pain, you may also have pain in your leg, hip, or on the bottom of your foot.
Weakness in your legs or feet

title: Low back pain - acute
alternate_names: Backache; Low back pain; Lumbar pain; Pain - back; Acute back pain; Back pain - new; Back pain - short-term; Back strain - new
symptoms: You may feel a variety of symptoms if you have hurt your back. You may have a tingling or burning sensation, a dull achy feeling, or sharp pain. The pain may be mild, or it can be so severe that you are unable to move.
Depending on the cause of your back pain, you may also have pain in your leg, hip, or the bottom of your foot. You may also have weakness in your legs and feet.

title: Carotid artery disease
alternate_names: Carotid stenosis; Stenosis - carotid; Stroke - carotid artery; TIA - carotid artery
symptoms: At early stages, you may not have any symptoms. After plaque builds up, the first symptoms of carotid artery disease may be a stroke or a transient ischemic attack (TIA). A TIA is temporary reduction in blood flow to the brain that doesn't cause any lasting damage.
Symptoms of stroke and TIA include:
Loss of sensation in one part of your body
Problems with speech and language, including loss of speech
Weakness in one part of your body
Problems with thinking, reasoning, and memory

title: Dysarthria
alternate_names: Impairment of speech; Slurred speech; Speech disorders - dysarthria
symptoms: Depending on its cause, dysarthria may develop slowly or occur suddenly.
People with dysarthria have trouble making certain sounds or words.
Their speech is poorly pronounced (such as slurring), and the rhythm or speed of their speech changes. Other symptoms include:
A person with dysarthria may also drool and have problems chewing or swallowing. It may be hard to move the lips, tongue, or jaw.
Sounding as though they are mumbling
Speaking softly or in a whisper
Speaking in a nasal or stuffy, hoarse, strained, or breathy voice

title: Apraxia
alternate_names: Verbal apraxia; Dyspraxia; Speech disorder - apraxia; Childhood apraxia of speech; Apraxia of speech; Acquired apraxia
symptoms: A person with apraxia is unable to put together the correct order of muscle movements. At times, a completely different word or action is used or occurs than the one the person intended to speak or make. The person is often aware of the mistake.
Symptoms of apraxia of speech include:
Distorted, repeated, or left out speech sounds or words. The person has difficulty putting words together in the correct order.
Struggling to pronounce the right word.
More difficulty using longer words, either all the time, or sometimes.
Ability to use short, everyday phrases or sayings (such as "How are you?") without a problem.
Better writing ability than speaking ability.
Buccofacial or orofacial apraxia. Inability to carry out movements of the face on demand, such as licking the lips, sticking out the tongue, or whistling.
Ideational apraxia. Inability to carry out learned, complex tasks in the proper order, such as putting on socks before putting on shoes.
Ideomotor apraxia. Inability to voluntarily perform a learned task when given the necessary objects. For instance, if given a screwdriver, the person may try to write with it as if it were a pen.

Limb-kinetic apraxia. Difficulty making precise movements with an arm or leg. It becomes impossible to button a shirt or tie a shoe. In gait apraxia, it becomes impossible for a person to take even a small step. Gait apraxia is commonly seen in normal pressure hydrocephalus.

title: Methamphetamine overdose
alternate_names: Intoxication - amphetamines; Intoxication - uppers; Amphetamine intoxication; Uppers overdose; Overdose - methamphetamine; Crank overdose; Meth overdose; Crystal meth overdose; Speed overdose; Ice overdose
symptoms: Methamphetamine most often causes a general feeling of wellness (euphoria) that is most often called a "rush." Other symptoms are increased heart rate, increased blood pressure, sweating, restlessness, dry mouth, elevated body temperature, and large, wide pupils.
If you take a large amount of the drug, you will be at higher risk for more dangerous side effects, including:
Long-term use of methamphetamine can lead to significant psychological problems, including:
The length of time methamphetamines stay active can be much longer than for cocaine and other stimulants. Some paranoid delusions can last for 15 hours.
Kidney damage and possibly kidney failure

Vaginal or uterine bleeding
alternate_names: Irregular menstruation; Heavy, prolonged, or irregular periods; Menorrhagia; Polymenorrhea; Metrorrhagia and other menstrual conditions; Abnormal menstrual periods; Abnormal vaginal bleeding
symptoms: Symptoms of abnormal vaginal bleeding include:
Bleeding from the rectum or blood in the urine may be mistaken for vaginal bleeding. To know for certain, insert a tampon into the vagina and check for bleeding.
Keep a record of your symptoms and bring these notes to your doctor. Your record should include:
Bleeding more heavily (passing large clots, needing to change protection during the night, soaking through a sanitary pad or tampon every hour for 2 to 3 hours in a row)
Bleeding for more days than normal or for more than 7 days
Menstrual cycle less than 28 days (more common) or more than 35 days apart
Bleeding after you have gone through menopause
Heavy bleeding associated with anemia (low blood count, low iron)
How much flow you have (count numbers of pads and tampons used, noting whether they are soaked)
Bleeding between periods and after sex

You may have problems swallowing with any eating or drinking, or only with certain types of foods or liquids. Early signs of swallowing problems may include difficulty when eating:
Cough or wheezing that becomes worse.
Regurgitating food that has not been digested.
Difficulty swallowing only solids (may indicate a tumor or stricture) suggests a physical blockage such as a stricture or a tumor.
Difficulty swallowing liquids but not solids (may indicate nerve damage or spasm of the esophagus).
